title: Cooking Project — Trail Mix
description: The child measures, combines, and mixes ingredients to create a simple trail mix. This cooking project introduces measuring cups and following a recipe with multiple steps.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Review the recipe card together.
2. Name each ingredient: raisins, pretzels, cereal, sunflower seeds, dried cranberries.
3. Demonstrate measuring 1/2 cup of raisins and pouring into the mixing bowl.
4. Child measures each ingredient, leveling the measuring cup.
5. Stir gently with a wooden spoon.
6. Scoop trail mix into a small bag or cup for snack.
7. Clean up: wipe table, wash bowl and spoon, put ingredients away.

slides.heading: Cooking Project
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! We're going to make something super yummy today called trail mix! It's like a special snack mix we get to make all by ourselves.

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange all ingredients in small bowls on a tray. Place the recipe card where the child can see it. Have the mixing bowl and measuring cup ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our yummy trail mix! We have some chewy raisins, crunchy pretzels, yummy cereal, and tasty seeds and cranberries. We also need special cups for measuring and a big bowl to mix everything in, plus a spoon. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Today we are following a RECIPE to make trail mix! A recipe tells us exactly what to put in and how much.' Read the recipe card together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we get to be chefs and follow a recipe to make our trail mix! A recipe is like a treasure map that tells us all the yummy things we need and how much to put in. We'll look at it together to make sure we make the best trail mix ever!

slides.text: Demonstrate: scoop raisins into the 1/2 cup measure. 'See how I fill it up and then level the top? That is how we measure carefully.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how I'm scooping the raisins into this cup? We want to fill it all the way up and then make the top flat, like this. This is how we make sure we have just the right amount of each yummy thing!

slides.text: 'Pour it into the big bowl. Now your turn! Measure 1/2 cup of pretzels.' Guide leveling if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super measurer! We're going to pour these pretzels into the cup, just like I did with the raisins. Then, you get to tip them into the big bowl. Watch them go!

slides.text: 'Keep going through the recipe — cereal, sunflower seeds, cranberries. Check off each ingredient on the recipe card as you add it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're doing so great! Now we get to add the cereal, then the seeds, and then the cranberries. For each one, we fill our measuring cup and put it in the big bowl. Let's check them off on our recipe map as we go!

slides.prompt: Measure and add all the remaining ingredients. Stir everything together gently. Scoop your trail mix into a bag for snack time!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, all the yummy things are in the bowl! Now, let's stir it all together gently with our spoon to mix up all the flavors. Then, we'll put our super trail mix into a little bag to eat for our snack!

slides.text: Enjoy your trail mix! Wash the bowl, spoon, and measuring cup. Wipe down the table. Put ingredient containers away.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow a multi-step recipe card, measure with a 1/2 cup, and clean up independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! Our trail mix looks so good and we made it ourselves by following the recipe! Now, let's be super helpers and clean up our kitchen by washing our bowl and spoon and wiping the table. You were such a good chef today!

parent_notes: Cooking is one of the most complete Montessori practical life activities — it involves sequencing (following a recipe), math (measuring), reading (recipe card), fine motor skills (pouring, stirring), and care of environment (cleanup). A picture recipe card is essential at this age: draw or print images of each ingredient next to the amount. Let the child check off each step. Trail mix is ideal because there is no cooking involved, and the child can adjust ingredients to taste. This builds toward more complex recipes in later weeks.
household_substitutes: Ingredients as listed in the lesson
preparation_steps: Wash hands first. Set out all ingredients and tools before calling the child. Pre-wash produce.
control_of_error: The finished food item shows the result. Taste-testing is the best self-check!
extension_ideas: Let the child serve the food to family
Draw or write about what you made
Try a variation with different ingredients

title: Phonograms — ai and oa
description: Introduction to the long vowel phonograms 'ai' (as in rain) and 'oa' (as in boat). The child learns that two letters together can make one long vowel sound.
instructions:
1. 'You know that letters make sounds. Sometimes TWO letters work together to make ONE sound.'
2. Present the 'ai' sandpaper phonogram card. Trace: 'This says /ay/ as in rain.'
3. Three-period lesson for 'ai': 'Show me ai. What does this say?'
4. Present 'oa': 'This says /oh/ as in boat.'
5. Three-period lesson for 'oa'.
6. Build words with moveable alphabet: rain, tail, mail, boat, coat, road.
7. Child reads each word after building.
materials_needed: Picture cards: rain, tail, mail, boat, coat, road

slides.heading: Phonograms
slides.subheading: ai and oa — Long Vowel Teams
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It’s all about special letter teams that make long sounds, like "ai" and "oa." We're going to learn how these two letters work together to make a big sound, just like some other letters we know!

slides.setup_instructions: Have sandpaper phonogram cards ready. Prepare picture cards to match words that will be built.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some special things to use today! We have these bumpy cards with "ai" and "oa" on them – touching them helps us remember the sound. We also have little letter pieces to build words and some pictures to match. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these fun things so we can play!

slides.text: 'Remember sh, ch, and th? Those were two letters making one sound. Today we learn two MORE! These make long vowel sounds.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how sometimes two letters, like 's' and 'h' together, make just one sound like "sh"? Well, we're going to learn about two more special letter teams today that do the same thing! They make long vowel sounds that you'll hear in lots of words.

slides.text: Trace 'ai' on the sandpaper card. 'This says /ay/. When you see a-i together, they say /ay/ like in RAIN.' Child traces three times.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this bumpy card? It has "ai" on it. Let's trace it with our finger! When you see 'a' and 'i' together like this, they make a special sound: /ay/. Say it with me: /ay/, just like in the word "rain" when it falls from the sky!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is ai.' 'Show me ai.' 'What does this say?' Then present 'oa': 'This says /oh/ like in BOAT.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to practice! First, I'll say "This is ai," and you find it. Then I'll say "Show me ai," and you point to it. Lastly, I'll ask "What does this say?" and you tell me the /ay/ sound! We'll do the same thing with "oa," which makes the /oh/ sound, like in "boat."

slides.text: 'Let us build words! R-AI-N. The ai says /ay/.' Build: rain, tail, mail. Then: boat, coat, road.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let’s build some words with our little letters! We'll put 'r', then 'ai', then 'n' together. Remember, 'ai' says /ay/, so we read it as "rain"! Then we'll build "tail" and "mail," and after that, we'll build "boat," "coat," and "road."

slides.prompt: Build three 'ai' words and three 'oa' words with the moveable alphabet. Read each one aloud. Match them to the picture cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to build and read! Can you find the letter pieces to make "rain"? Great job! Now say it out loud, "rain"! Next, let's build "boat" and say "boat." We'll build three words with "ai" and three with "oa," then match them to the pictures. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Two letters can work as a team! ai says /ay/ and oa says /oh/. You will see these in many books!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the sounds of 'ai' and 'oa' and read at least 3 words containing each phonogram?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You learned that two letters can be a team and make one sound. "Ai" says /ay/, like in "rain," and "oa" says /oh/, like in "boat." You're going to see these letter teams everywhere when you read books! You’re such a super reader!

parent_notes: Phonograms (also called digraphs or vowel teams) are a key step in reading development. The child has already learned consonant digraphs (sh, ch, th). Now we introduce vowel teams where two vowels together make a long vowel sound. The rule 'when two vowels go walking, the first one does the talking' applies here: in 'ai' you hear the long /a/, in 'oa' you hear the long /o/. Present only two phonograms at a time to avoid confusion. The sandpaper cards provide the tactile input that reinforces memory. Building words immediately shows the child how phonograms function in real reading.

title: Golden Bead Multiplication — Introduction
description: The child discovers multiplication as 'taking the same quantity several times.' Using golden beads, they build the same number on multiple trays and combine them to find the product.
instructions:
1. 'We have learned to add different numbers. Today we will do something new — multiplication!'
2. 'Multiplication means taking the SAME number MORE THAN ONCE.'
3. Give the child 3 trays. 'Put 12 on each tray: 1 ten bar and 2 units.'
4. 'We have 12, three times! 12 taken 3 times.'
5. Combine all beads: 3 ten bars + 6 units = 36.
6. '12 taken 3 times gives us 36! That is multiplication.'
7. Repeat with 11 taken 4 times (44), then 13 taken 2 times (26).

slides.heading: Golden Bead Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Golden Bead Multiplication," and that means we're going to learn a new way to count. We'll be taking the same number and counting it lots of times, like when you count your teddy bears more than once!

items: Golden beads: units, ten bars, hundred square
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the floor mat. Place golden beads in the bank area. Have 3-4 small trays ready for the child to build identical quantities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have so many cool things to play with for our math game today! We have these shiny golden beads that help us count, and these little trays to build on. We also have a big mat to spread out on the floor, and some special number cards. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these treasures so we can start playing!

slides.text: 'In addition we put DIFFERENT numbers together. Multiplication is different — we take the SAME number again and again!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We already know how to put different numbers together, like one block and then another block. But today, we're going to learn something new called multiplication! It's like doing the same thing over and over again, instead of picking new things each time.

slides.text: 'Let us take 12, three times. Build 12 on this tray: 1 ten bar and 2 units.' Child builds. 'Now build 12 again on this tray. And again on the third tray.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's build the number 12 together! We'll take one long stick, that's our 'ten,' and then two little dots, that's our 'ones.' Now, we need to make three of these groups of 12, so let's build it again on the next tray, and then one more time on the third tray. We're making the same number three times!

slides.text: 'We have 12... 12... 12. Three groups of 12! Now bring them all together.' Combine: count ten bars (3), count units (6). 'That is 36!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have three piles of 12! Let's put all our long 'ten' sticks together – how many do we have? And now let's count all the little 'ones' dots. Wow, when we put them all together, we get a brand new number!

slides.text: '12 taken 3 times equals 36. That is MULTIPLICATION!' Place numeral cards: 12 x 3 = 36.
slides.mascot_explanation: See? We took the number 12, and we did it three times. And when we counted everything up, we got 36! That's called multiplication – it's like a super-fast way to count when you have the same thing many times.

slides.prompt: Try 11 taken 4 times. Build 11 on four trays. Combine them. What do you get? Then try 13 taken 2 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the multiplication wizard! Let's try building the number 11 four times on four different trays. Then, we'll count them all up and see what we get! After that, we can try another one, building the number 13 two times. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Multiplication is taking the same number many times and combining. You just multiplied with golden beads!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build identical quantities on multiple trays and combine them to find the product?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You were a multiplication superstar today, taking the same number and counting it many times. We used those shiny golden beads to make groups and found out how many we had altogether. That's exactly what multiplication is!

parent_notes: Montessori introduces multiplication concretely long before memorizing times tables. The key language is 'taken X times' rather than 'times' or 'multiplied by' initially. The child physically builds the same quantity on separate trays (representing groups), then combines them. This makes multiplication visible as repeated addition. Do not rush to symbols — let the child experience many rounds of building, combining, and counting. The golden beads make exchange natural: if 14 taken 3 times yields 12 units, the child already knows to exchange 10 units for a ten bar. This builds directly on their addition with exchange experience.

title: Puzzle Map — Europe
description: Introduction to the Europe puzzle map. The child learns to identify the continent of Europe and several major countries by their shapes and positions.
instructions:
1. Review the world puzzle map: 'Which continent is this?' Point to Europe.
2. Present the Europe puzzle map. Remove all pieces.
3. 'Europe has many countries close together. Let us learn a few.'
4. Start with large, distinctive pieces: France, Spain, Italy, United Kingdom, Germany.
5. Name each as you place it: 'This is Italy. See how it looks like a boot?'
6. Three-period lesson for 3-4 countries.
7. Child rebuilds the puzzle independently.

slides.heading: Puzzle Map
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Puzzle Map" and "Europe." That means we're going to play with a special puzzle of a place called Europe! It's like a big puzzle of a faraway land.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the Europe puzzle map on the mat. Have the world map nearby for context. Keep the control map face-down until needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our puzzle adventure! We have the big Europe puzzle, a map of the whole world, a picture map, a special mat, and even a globe that looks like a ball! Let's get our mat ready and put the big Europe puzzle on it.

slides.text: 'We have explored North America and South America. Today we travel across the ocean to EUROPE!' Show Europe on the globe and world map.
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned about other big places, but now we get to go on a trip to a new place! This is called Europe, and we'll find it on our globe and our world map. It's across the big, big ocean!

slides.text: Remove all pieces. 'Europe has many countries — more than the other maps we have done! Let us start with a few big ones.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's take all the pieces out of the Europe puzzle. Europe has lots and lots of countries all snuggled together, so we'll learn some of the biggest ones first. It's like finding the biggest shapes in a new puzzle!

slides.text: 'This is ITALY — see how it looks like a boot kicking a ball? And this is SPAIN — it is next to the ocean.' Place each piece as you name it.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this piece? It looks like a funny boot kicking a ball, and that's ITALY! And right next to it is SPAIN, which is by the big blue ocean. We're going to put these pieces right where they belong.

slides.text: 'This is FRANCE — it is right next to Spain. And across the water, this island is the UNITED KINGDOM.' Place Germany: 'GERMANY is in the middle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this piece is FRANCE, and it's right next to Spain. And look across the water – this big island is the UNITED KINGDOM! Germany is in the middle of these other countries. We're learning so many new places!

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me France.' 'Where is Italy?' 'What country is this?' Then try rebuilding the whole puzzle!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the puzzle master! Can you show me where France is? And can you find Italy? Let's put all the pieces back in their homes. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You learned countries in Europe! Next time we will learn about the people and cultures in these places.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place at least 4 European countries on the puzzle map?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned the shapes of countries in Europe, like Italy and France! Next time, we'll learn even more cool things about these places. You are such a super learner!

parent_notes: The Montessori geography curriculum progresses from the whole (globe) to parts (continents) to details (countries). Europe has many small pieces, which can be challenging. Start with the 4-5 largest and most recognizable countries. Italy's boot shape is a wonderful mnemonic. Do not expect mastery of all countries — this is an introduction. The child will return to this map many times. You can extend this work by looking at pictures of these countries, trying foods from each culture, or listening to music. The control map (with country names printed) serves as a self-correcting reference.

title: Read-Aloud: Stone Soup (retold by Marcia Brown)
description: A classic folktale about resourcefulness, sharing, and community. Three soldiers convince a village to contribute ingredients for a communal soup, connecting to the cooking theme.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is an old story called Stone Soup. What do you think stone soup is?'
2. Read aloud with expression, pausing for predictions.
3. After the villagers start contributing: 'Why do you think they changed their minds?'
4. Discuss: 'Was it really the stone that made the soup taste good? What made it good?'
5. 'Have you ever shared something and ended up with more than you started with?'
6. Optional: make a simple soup together, starting with a clean stone!
materials_needed: Stone Soup by Marcia Brown (or any retelling)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this picture! It's the cover of a special book for a story we're going to read together. It's called "Stone Soup," and it's a very, very old story!

items: Optional: a clean stone as a prop
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If using a stone prop, wash it thoroughly.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our story today, we have some special things ready! We have the "Stone Soup" book, and maybe a nice, clean stone we can pretend with. We also have some paper and crayons for drawing later!

slides.text: Show the cover. 'This is a very old story that people have told for hundreds of years! It is called Stone Soup. Can you really make soup from a stone?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to look at the front of our book! This is a super old story called "Stone Soup." What do you think it means to make soup out of a stone? Do you think it will be yummy?

slides.text: Read aloud. When the soldiers start the soup: 'They are cooking a stone! Do you think it will taste good?' Pause as villagers contribute ingredients.
slides.mascot_explanation: We are going to read the story now! Listen closely. The soldiers are putting a stone in the pot to make soup. Do you think that stone makes the soup taste good all by itself?

slides.text: After reading: 'Was the stone the real secret? What actually made the soup delicious?' Guide toward: everyone sharing a little made something wonderful.
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished the story! Was the stone really what made the soup taste so good? What do you think made it taste so yummy for everyone?

slides.prompt: Draw your favorite part of the story. Or draw what YOU would add to the soup if you were a villager. Label your drawing if you can.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! You can draw your favorite part of the Stone Soup story. Or, you can draw something yummy you would put in the soup if you were one of the people in the village!

slides.text: 'When everyone shares a little, we end up with something amazing. That is the lesson of Stone Soup!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic story and explain the message about sharing and community?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned that when everyone shares just a little bit of what they have, it can make something super special for everyone! That's the magic of Stone Soup!

parent_notes: Stone Soup connects beautifully to the cooking practical life work this week. The story teaches about generosity, community, and resourcefulness without being preachy. There are many versions — Marcia Brown's is the classic, but Jon Muth's and Heather Forest's versions are also excellent. The deeper Montessori connection is to grace and courtesy and community living. After reading, you might actually make a simple vegetable soup together, ceremonially adding a clean stone to the pot. This makes the story come alive and gives another cooking experience.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Geometric Cabinet — Circle, Square, Triangle Drawers
description: The child explores the geometric cabinet drawers containing circles, squares, and triangles of graduated sizes. They practice tracing the insets and matching shapes to cards.
instructions:
1. Present the circle drawer. Remove the largest circle inset.
2. Demonstrate tracing the inside of the frame and then the outside of the inset with two fingers.
3. 'These are all circles, but they are different SIZES.' Grade from largest to smallest.
4. Present the square drawer. Trace and grade.
5. Present the triangle drawer. Trace and grade.
6. Introduce matching cards: solid, thick outline, thin outline.
7. Child matches insets to cards.

slides.heading: Geometric Cabinet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We are going to play with shapes today, like circles, squares, and triangles. We'll learn all about them with our special shape cabinet.

items: Geometric cabinet drawers: circles, squares, triangles
Three sets of matching cards per shape
slides.setup_instructions: Place the three drawers on the mat. Have matching cards sorted by shape in separate stacks.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these neat things! We have drawers with circles, squares, and triangles inside, and some special cards to match them with. We'll put them all on our big work mat to get ready to play.

slides.text: 'This cabinet holds flat shapes — let us explore three drawers today.' Open the circle drawer. Remove the largest circle by its knob.
slides.mascot_explanation: This drawer has lots of circles! See the big, big circle? We're going to take it out very gently using the little handle. This is our first shape to explore today.

slides.text: Demonstrate tracing: 'First trace INSIDE the frame with two fingers... then trace AROUND the inset.' Slow, deliberate movements. Child traces.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's use our fingers like magic! First, we trace the empty space where the circle was, like we're drawing it with our finger. Then, we trace the edge of the circle we took out. It's like giving the shape a gentle hug with our fingers!

slides.text: 'All of these are circles, but look — they go from BIG to SMALL. Can you put them in order?' Grade all circles from largest to smallest.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these circles! They look like friends, but they're all different sizes, from super big to little-peewee small. Can you help me put them in order, starting with the biggest one?

slides.text: Repeat with squares and triangles. 'How are squares different from circles? Squares have corners and straight sides!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have a drawer of squares and a drawer of triangles! We'll trace them with our fingers just like we did with the circles. Squares have pointy corners and straight sides, not like smooth circles!

slides.prompt: Match each shape inset to its card: first the solid card (filled in), then the thick outline, then the thin outline. Can you match all of them?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a matching game! We have our shapes, and we have cards with pictures of the shapes. Can you find the card that looks just like the circle, then the one that looks like the square, and then the triangle? Let's see if we can match them all up!

slides.text: 'You traced and sorted three different shapes in many sizes. Your fingers are learning what shapes feel like!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly trace, grade by size, and match shapes to all three card types?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job today! We traced circles, squares, and triangles, and we put them in order from big to small. Your fingers are super smart at feeling all the different shapes!

parent_notes: The geometric cabinet is a cornerstone sensorial material that prepares the child for geometry. The three sets of matching cards progress in abstraction: solid (filled shape), thick outline, thin outline. This mirrors the Montessori principle of moving from concrete to abstract. Tracing with two fingers (index and middle) prepares the hand for writing while building the muscular memory of shape. The child is internalizing properties of shapes — curves vs. straight edges, number of sides, symmetry — all through the hand. If you do not have the full cabinet, you can create paper insets and cards.

title: Phonograms — ee and oo
description: Introduction to the double vowel phonograms 'ee' (as in tree) and 'oo' (as in moon). The child traces sandpaper phonogram cards and builds words with the moveable alphabet.
instructions:
1. Review ai and oa from yesterday.
2. Present 'ee': 'Two e's together say /ee/ as in tree.'
3. Trace the sandpaper card. Three-period lesson.
4. Present 'oo': 'Two o's together say /oo/ as in moon.'
5. Trace and three-period lesson.
6. Build words: tree, see, bee, feet, moon, spoon, food, zoo.
7. Child reads each word. Sort words into 'ee' and 'oo' columns.
materials_needed: Picture cards: tree, bee, feet, moon, spoon, zoo

slides.heading: Phonograms
slides.subheading: ee and oo — Double Vowel Sounds
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to learn about special sounds that letters make when they hold hands. We'll learn about the "ee" sound, like in "tree," and the "oo" sound, like in "moon."

slides.setup_instructions: Have ee and oo sandpaper cards ready. Set out moveable alphabet and picture cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our lesson! We have special cards with bumpy letters, like a magic alphabet, and some pictures to help us. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play with them?

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned ai and oa. Today we meet two more vowel teams! These ones use the SAME letter twice.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday when we learned about the "ai" and "oa" sounds? Well, today we have two more super sounds to learn! These sounds are made when two of the same letter get together, like best friends.

slides.text: Present 'ee': 'Two e's side by side say /ee/. Like in TREE and BEE.' Child traces three times. Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to learn the "ee" sound! See how the two 'e's are holding hands? When they do that, they say "ee," like in the word "tree" or "bee." Let's trace the bumpy letter with our finger!

slides.text: Present 'oo': 'Two o's say /oo/. Like in MOON and SPOON.' Child traces. Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the "oo" sound! Look, two 'o's are together, and they say "oo," just like in "moon" or "spoon." Let's feel that sound with our fingers as we trace the bumpy letters.

slides.text: 'Let us build words! T-R-EE. The ee says /ee/.' Build: tree, see, bee, feet. Then: moon, spoon, food, zoo.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build words with our magic alphabet! We'll put letters together to make words like "tree," "see," and "bee." Then we'll build words with the "oo" sound, like "moon" and "spoon."

slides.prompt: Build 4 'ee' words and 4 'oo' words. Read each one. Sort them into two columns. Match words to picture cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play a word game! We'll build words that have the "ee" sound and words that have the "oo" sound, and then we'll read them. We can even match them to the pictures to see what they mean!

slides.text: 'You know four phonograms now: ai, oa, ee, oo! These help you read so many more words.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read words containing ee and oo and sort them correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today! We learned not just one, but four special sounds: "ai," "oa," "ee," and "oo." That means you can read even more words now, just like a big kid!

parent_notes: Double vowel phonograms are satisfying for children because the pattern is visually simple — the same letter twice. Note that 'oo' actually has two common sounds: /oo/ as in moon and /uh/ as in book. For now, introduce only the long /oo/ sound. The short sound will come later. If the child encounters 'book' or 'look,' simply say, 'Sometimes oo says /uh/ instead — English is tricky!' Do not belabor the exception. The moveable alphabet continues to be the primary tool for encoding (building) words, while reading the built words develops decoding skills. Both skills develop together.

title: Golden Bead Multiplication — Practice with Bead Bars
description: The child practices multiplication using colored bead bars. Each bead bar represents a number, making it efficient to 'take a number multiple times' by laying out identical bead bars.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Multiplication means taking the same number several times.'
2. Introduce bead bars: 'This bar has 4 beads — it represents 4.'
3. 'Let us take 4, three times.' Lay out three 4-bars side by side.
4. Count all beads: 4 + 4 + 4 = 12.
5. Record: 4 taken 3 times = 12.
6. Practice: 3 taken 5 times (15), 5 taken 4 times (20), 2 taken 6 times (12).
7. Child selects a bead bar and chooses how many times to take it.

slides.heading: Multiplication with Bead Bars
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to learn something super fun with these colorful sticks called bead bars! It's like a magic trick for numbers where we can make big numbers by putting smaller numbers together many times. Get ready to be a number wizard!

items: Colored bead bars (sets of each number)
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange bead bars by color/number on the mat. Have enough of each number for multiple groups.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful things! We have these long colorful sticks called bead bars, and each one is a number. We also have a special mat to put them on, some number cards, and paper and a pencil to write down our math magic. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play?

slides.text: 'Yesterday we multiplied with golden beads on trays. Today we use bead bars! Each bar is a number.' Show the 4-bar: 'Count the beads — this is 4.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these colorful bead bars? Each little stick is a number! Let's count the beads on this one. One, two, three, four! So this stick is the number 4. We're going to use these to help us count in a super fast way!

slides.text: 'Let us take 4, three times.' Lay three 4-bars in a row. 'One group of 4... two groups of 4... three groups of 4.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend we have the number 4, and we want to have it three times. Watch me! We'll put one stick of 4 here, then another stick of 4 right next to it, and then one more stick of 4. See? We have the number 4, three times!

slides.text: 'Count all the beads together: 4, 8, 12! Four taken three times equals 12.' Place numeral cards: 4 x 3 = 12.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count all the little beads together to see how many we have! We have 4 here, and 4 more, and 4 more. If we count them all, we get 12! So, 4 taken three times makes 12. We're doing great!

slides.text: 'Try 3 taken 5 times.' Child lays five 3-bars and counts: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! Let's see if we can take the number 3, and have it five times. Can you find five of the '3' bead bars and put them in a row? Then we can count them all together to see what number we make!

slides.prompt: Choose a bead bar. Decide how many times to take it. Lay them out, count the total, and record the result. Try at least 3 different multiplications!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! You get to pick any bead bar you want, and then decide how many times you want to take it. Lay them all out, count them up, and write down your super math answer. Let's try at least three different ones!

slides.text: 'Bead bars make multiplication quick — you can see all the groups lined up! You are becoming a multiplier!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select a bead bar, lay out the correct number of groups, and count to find the product?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such an amazing math helper! You used the bead bars to show how numbers can be taken many times, and you counted them all so fast. You're becoming a real multiplication star, and that's super cool!

parent_notes: The colored bead bars are a bridge between the large golden bead material and abstract multiplication. Each number has its own color (1=red, 2=green, 3=pink, 4=yellow, 5=light blue, 6=purple, 7=white, 8=brown, 9=dark blue, 10=gold). Laying out identical bars in rows makes the concept of equal groups visually clear. The child may naturally begin skip counting (4, 8, 12...) which is wonderful — this is the foundation of times tables. Do not drill facts; let the pattern emerge through repeated concrete experience. Some children enjoy recording their results in a little multiplication book.

title: Animal Kingdom — Vertebrates and Invertebrates
description: Introduction to the first great division of the animal kingdom: animals with backbones (vertebrates) and animals without (invertebrates). The child sorts animal pictures into two groups.
instructions:
1. 'All animals belong to a big family called the Animal Kingdom. Today we learn the FIRST way to sort them.'
2. Feel your own backbone: 'Run your hand down the middle of your back. Feel those bumps? That is your BACKBONE or SPINE.'
3. 'Some animals have a backbone like us — they are called VERTEBRATES.' Show pictures: cat, fish, bird, frog, snake.
4. 'Some animals have NO backbone — they are INVERTEBRATES.' Show: worm, butterfly, jellyfish, spider, snail.
5. Sort picture cards into two groups.
6. 'Which group has MORE animals in the world? Invertebrates — by far!'

slides.heading: Animal Kingdom
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big title! It says "Animal Kingdom," which is like a giant family for ALL the animals in the world. We're going to learn how to sort them into special groups today!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare picture cards of 5+ vertebrates and 5+ invertebrates. Make two label cards. Place on mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to use some fun things! We have these cool pictures of animals, and some special signs that say "Vertebrate" and "Invertebrate." We also have a mat to put them on. You can ask a grown-up to help you get these ready for our game!

slides.text: 'The Animal Kingdom is HUGE — millions of different animals! Scientists sort them into groups. The first big question is: Does it have a BACKBONE?'
slides.mascot_explanation: All the animals in the world live in a super big family called the Animal Kingdom. Today, we're going to learn the very first way to sort them into two groups. It's all about whether they have something special inside their bodies called a backbone.

slides.text: 'Feel your back — those bumps are your backbone! Animals with backbones are called VERTEBRATES.' Show pictures: cat, fish, bird, frog, snake. 'All of these have backbones inside.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's feel our own backs! Can you run your hand down your back and feel those little bumps? That's your backbone, like a strong support inside you! Animals that have a backbone like us are called vertebrates, just like this kitty cat and this fishy.

slides.text: 'Animals WITHOUT backbones are called INVERTEBRATES.' Show: worm, butterfly, jellyfish, spider, snail. 'These are soft or have their hard parts on the OUTSIDE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, some animals don't have a backbone inside their body at all! We call them invertebrates. Think about a wiggly worm or a pretty butterfly – they are soft and squishy or have their hard parts on the outside, not a backbone inside.

slides.text: 'Here is a surprising fact: MOST animals on Earth are invertebrates! Insects alone outnumber all vertebrates combined.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here’s a super surprising thing! Most of the animals in the whole wide world do NOT have a backbone. There are SO many more invertebrates than vertebrates, like all the little bugs and creepy crawlies!

slides.prompt: Sort the animal picture cards into two groups: Vertebrate and Invertebrate. For each card, ask yourself: does this animal have a backbone inside its body?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super sorter! We're going to take each animal picture and decide if it has a backbone (that's a vertebrate!) or if it doesn't (that's an invertebrate!). Put them in the right piles, and let's see what you can do!

slides.text: 'You made the first big division of the Animal Kingdom! Next we will learn the five groups of vertebrates.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the difference between vertebrates and invertebrates and correctly sort at least 8 out of 10 animal cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You helped sort the animals into the two big groups: those with backbones and those without! That was the first big way to understand the animal kingdom, and you are so smart!

parent_notes: Montessori zoology begins with the big picture — the entire animal kingdom — and progressively narrows. This top-down approach gives children a framework for organizing all future animal knowledge. The vertebrate/invertebrate division is the first branching point. Let the child feel their own spine first — this embodied experience makes the abstract concept concrete. Some children are fascinated to learn that 97% of all animal species are invertebrates! If the child asks about specific animals (Is a shark a vertebrate? What about a crab?), welcome these questions — curiosity drives Montessori learning. A shark has a cartilage skeleton, but it is still a vertebrate. A crab has an exoskeleton and is an invertebrate.

title: Watercolor Painting — Wet on Wet Technique
description: Introduction to wet-on-wet watercolor painting. The child learns to wet the paper first, then apply color, watching how pigments flow and blend on a damp surface.
instructions:
1. 'Today we try a special way to paint. We will make the paper WET first!'
2. Demonstrate preparing the workspace: watercolor paper, paint palette, two water jars, large brush.
3. Dip the large brush in clean water and paint the entire paper with water.
4. 'Now choose a color and touch it to the wet paper. Watch what happens!'
5. The color will spread and bloom. 'On wet paper, the paint moves on its own!'
6. Add a second color near the first — they will blend.
7. Let the child create freely. When finished, lay flat to dry.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn a super fun way to paint today called "Wet on Wet." It sounds like magic, doesn't it? We're going to make our paintings look so cool!

items: Two water jars (one for rinsing, one for clean water)
slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Set out two water jars, paints, and paper. Put on the painting smock.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our painting adventure! We have special paper, yummy colors in little pots, and a big fluffy brush. We also have two cups of water – one for rinsing our brush and one for making the paper wet, and a sponge to catch any drips. Don't forget your smock to keep your clothes clean!

slides.text: 'Today we paint in a new way! First, we make the whole paper wet with clean water.' Demonstrate brushing water across the entire page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first things first! We need to get our paper all wet, like it's taking a bath. Take your big brush and dip it in the clean water, then paint all over your paper until it's shiny and wet. This is the special start to our magical painting!

slides.text: 'Now pick a color. Gently touch your brush to the wet paper...' Watch the color bloom and spread. 'See how it moves on its own? The water carries the paint!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part! Pick your favorite color and gently touch it to the wet paper with your brush. See how the color starts to spread out all by itself? It's like the water is helping the paint dance and play!

slides.text: 'Pick a second color. Put it near the first one. Watch them meet and blend! You cannot control exactly what happens — that is the beauty of this technique.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another color! Pick a different color and put it near the first one. Watch them wiggle and jiggle and mix together like best friends! Isn't it amazing how they blend on the wet paper?

slides.text: 'If your paper starts to dry, you can add more water with the clean brush. Rinse your brush between colors in the rinsing jar.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, our paper might get a little dry, and that's okay! If you see a spot that's not wet anymore, just dip your brush in the clean water again and paint it. And remember to give your brush a little bath in the other cup when you switch colors!

slides.prompt: Create your own wet-on-wet painting. Experiment with different colors meeting each other. What happens when warm colors meet cool colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You can paint anything you like using this special wet-on-wet way. Try putting different colors together and see what beautiful surprises happen. You have lots of time to make something wonderful!

slides.text: Lay your painting flat to dry. Clean your brush, empty the water jars, and wipe down your workspace. Sign your painting when it is dry!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet the paper, apply colors, and observe blending? Does the child clean up independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you made a beautiful painting! Now, let's help clean up so our painting can dry nicely. Carefully lay your artwork flat, give your brush a good rinse, and help wipe up any water. We did such a great job painting today!

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is deeply connected to Waldorf and Montessori art education. It develops the child's relationship with color and teaches acceptance of what cannot be fully controlled — a profound life lesson. The paint moves and blends in unexpected ways, which delights children. Use thick paper (140lb or higher) so it does not buckle. Two water jars are essential: one for rinsing the brush, one for clean water to wet the paper. Limit colors to 2-3 initially to avoid muddy results. Primary colors (red, blue, yellow) show the most dramatic blending into secondary colors. Do not direct what the child should paint — process over product is the philosophy here.
household_substitutes: Cup of water and paper towels
preparation_steps: Cover the work surface. Set out materials in order of use. Demonstrate technique first.
control_of_error: Art is self-expressive — focus on the process, not the product.
extension_ideas: Display the artwork proudly
Try the same subject with a different medium
Look at famous artwork for inspiration

title: Embroidery — Introduction to Running Stitch on Fabric
description: The child transitions from sewing cards to actual fabric embroidery. They learn to thread an embroidery needle, tie a knot, and make a running stitch line on burlap or Aida cloth.
instructions:
1. 'You have been sewing beautifully on cards. Today you will sew on REAL fabric!'
2. Show the embroidery hoop and fabric. Demonstrate securing fabric in the hoop.
3. Thread the needle with embroidery floss. Demonstrate tying a knot at the end.
4. Draw a simple straight line on the fabric with washable marker.
5. 'We will use the running stitch you already know: up, down, up, down — following the line.'
6. Demonstrate 3-4 stitches. Then hand to the child.
7. Child stitches along the line. When done, show how to tie off.

slides.heading: Embroidery
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn how to do something super special called embroidery. It's like sewing, but with pretty string on fabric!

slides.setup_instructions: Secure the burlap in the hoop beforehand. Cut a length of floss (about 18 inches). Draw a simple straight line on the fabric with the washable marker.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our sewing adventure! We have a hoop to hold our fabric tight, a special needle, some colorful string called floss, a marker to draw a line, scissors to cut the string, and a tray to keep everything neat. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'You have sewn on cards. Now we move to REAL fabric! This hoop holds the fabric tight so it is easy to sew.' Let the child feel the taut fabric.
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job sewing on those paper cards, and now we get to sew on real fabric! This hoop holds the fabric nice and stiff, so it's ready for us to make beautiful stitches. Feel how tight the fabric is!

slides.text: Thread the needle: 'Push the floss through the eye of the needle. Pull it through.' Demonstrate tying a knot at the bottom. Child attempts threading.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to get our string ready for the needle. We have to carefully push the string through the tiny hole at the end of the needle, and then we'll learn a special knot to keep it from slipping out. You can try it, and I'm right here to help!

slides.text: 'Start from the BACK. Push the needle up through the fabric right at the beginning of the line.' Show the first stitch: up through, then down a short distance ahead.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to start sewing from the back, where no one can see! We push the needle up through the fabric, right where our line starts. Then, we make a little stitch by going down a short way ahead of where we came up.

slides.text: 'Up, down, up, down — just like sewing cards, but on real fabric! Follow the line I drew.' Demonstrate 3-4 stitches.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we keep going, up and down, up and down, following the line we drew. It's just like sewing on your cards, but feel how the needle goes through the fabric! We're making a beautiful line together.

slides.prompt: Continue the running stitch along the line. Try to keep your stitches about the same size. When you reach the end, we will tie off the thread.
slides.mascot_explanation: You're doing so great with your running stitches! Keep going up and down, up and down, trying to make your stitches a nice, even size. When you get to the end of the line, we'll learn how to finish it off perfectly.

slides.text: Show how to tie off: loop under the last stitch and pull tight. 'You just did real embroidery! You can frame this or keep practicing.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child thread a needle, make a running stitch line on fabric, and tie off?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you finished! You made a real embroidery stitch on fabric! You can tie off the thread by making a little loop and pulling it tight, just like this. You are a super sewer, and you can keep this special picture you made!

parent_notes: Moving from sewing cards to real fabric is a significant milestone. Burlap or Aida cloth (cross-stitch fabric) is ideal because the weave is loose and visible — the child can see exactly where to put the needle. A small embroidery hoop (4-6 inches) keeps the fabric taut and manageable for small hands. Use a blunt tapestry needle for safety — it passes through loose-weave fabric easily. Thread should be about 18 inches — longer tangles easily. The running stitch is the same one learned on sewing cards, so the child has confidence. In Montessori, sewing develops concentration, fine motor control, patience, and a sense of accomplishment. Display finished work proudly.
household_substitutes: Large plastic needle or blunt tapestry needle
preparation_steps: Pre-punch holes in the fabric or card. Thread the needle and tie a knot at the end.
control_of_error: The stitching pattern shows whether the child followed the path correctly.
extension_ideas: Sew a simple pouch or felt ornament
Create a sewing card from cardboard
Practice different stitch patterns

title: Puzzle Words — the, a, is, was
description: Introduction to high-frequency 'puzzle words' (sight words) that cannot be sounded out phonetically. The child learns to recognize the, a, is, and was as whole words through multisensory practice.
instructions:
1. 'Most words follow the rules we have learned. But some words are PUZZLES — they do not follow the rules!'
2. Present 'the' on a card. 'This word is THE. It is in almost every sentence!'
3. Trace 'the' in sand tray. Say it three times.
4. Present 'a': 'This tiny word is A. It looks like the letter a but it says /uh/.'
5. Present 'is' and 'was' the same way.
6. Play a matching game: read a sentence strip and find the puzzle word.
7. Practice reading short sentences using puzzle words: 'The cat is big. A dog was here.'
materials_needed: Puzzle word cards: the, a, is, was

slides.heading: Puzzle Words
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We are going to learn some special words today called "Puzzle Words." They are called puzzle words because they are like little puzzles for our brains to remember!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards for the, a, is, was. Write 5-6 sentence strips using these words with phonetic words the child can decode.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have lots of fun things to play with for our puzzle words! We have some special cards with the words on them, a tray of sand to write in, and some strips of paper with sentences. We'll also use our letters to build our own sentences.

slides.text: 'You can sound out most words. But some words are tricky — they do not follow the rules. We call them PUZZLE WORDS because they are like little puzzles to remember.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know, most words are like a secret code we can sound out, but some words are like special surprises! They don't follow the rules and we have to remember them just as they are, like a fun puzzle.

slides.text: Hold up 'the.' 'This word is THE. It is the most common word in English! You will see it everywhere.' Trace it in the sand tray three times, saying 'the' each time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this word, it's "THE"! This is a super important word that we see almost everywhere, like in stories and when people talk. Let's trace it in the sand together three times and say "the" each time!

slides.text: Present 'a,' 'is,' and 'was' the same way. Trace each in the sand tray. Three-period lesson for all four words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have three more special words: "A," "IS," and "WAS"! We will trace these in the sand too, saying their names each time, just like we did with "THE." It's like giving them a special hug to remember them!

slides.text: Read sentence strips together: 'The cat is big.' 'A dog was here.' 'The sun is hot.' The child reads the phonetic words and the puzzle words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's read some sentences together! See how we have words we can sound out and our special puzzle words? We'll read them all, even the tricky ones!

slides.prompt: Read the sentence strips. Find and point to each puzzle word. Then build a sentence using the moveable alphabet that includes at least one puzzle word.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super reader! Can you find all the puzzle words in these sentences? Then, let's use our letter tiles to build your very own sentence with one of our new puzzle words. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know four puzzle words: the, a, is, was. These little words are in almost every book you will ever read!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recognize and read the, a, is, and was in isolation and within sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You learned four new puzzle words: "the," "a," "is," and "was"! These tiny words are like magic keys that help us read all sorts of books and stories. You did such a great job remembering them!

parent_notes: In Montessori language education, phonetically irregular high-frequency words are sometimes called 'puzzle words' or 'sight words.' The term 'puzzle words' is preferred because it implies the word is interesting (a puzzle to figure out) rather than something to memorize by rote (sight). The child should still attempt to sound out these words — 'the' starts with /th/ which they know — but the vowel sound is irregular. Tracing in the sand tray engages muscle memory. Introduce only 3-4 puzzle words per lesson. The sentence strips are crucial: seeing these words in context makes them meaningful. As the child encounters these words repeatedly in reading, recognition becomes automatic.

title: Stamp Game — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori stamp game. The child learns that small stamps can represent units, tens, hundreds, and thousands, providing a more abstract way to work with large numbers.
instructions:
1. 'You know golden beads well. Now I want to show you something new that works the same way but is smaller and easier to carry.'
2. Present the stamp game box. Open it and show the stamps.
3. 'Green stamps with 1 are UNITS. Blue stamps with 10 are TENS. Red stamps with 100 are HUNDREDS. Green stamps with 1000 are THOUSANDS.'
4. 'Build 2,345 with stamps.' Child counts out 2 thousands, 3 hundreds, 4 tens, 5 units.
5. Build several numbers. Compare to golden beads: 'One blue stamp equals one golden ten bar!'
6. Child builds 5 numbers independently.

slides.heading: The Stamp Game
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this slide! It says "The Stamp Game" and "Introduction." This means we are going to learn about something new and exciting called the stamp game!

slides.setup_instructions: Open the stamp game and lay out the stamps sorted by category. Place numeral cards nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our new game! We have a special box with little colorful stamps, a mat to work on, and cards with numbers. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready!

slides.text: 'The golden beads are wonderful but big. This box has tiny stamps that do the same job!' Open the stamp game box.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember our shiny golden beads? We used them to learn about numbers. This special box has tiny stamps that do the same job as the beads, but they are super small and easy to carry around!

slides.text: 'Green with 1 = units. Blue with 10 = tens. Red with 100 = hundreds. Green with 1000 = thousands. The COLORS match the numeral cards!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these colorful stamps! The green ones with a '1' are for the ones, the blue ones with a '10' are for the tens, the red ones with a '100' are for the hundreds, and the big green ones with a '1000' are for the thousands. The colors help us remember!

slides.text: 'Build 2,345. Start with the thousands: 1,000... 2,000. Now hundreds: 100, 200, 300. Tens: 10, 20, 30, 40. Units: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's build the number 2,345 together! We need two of the big green thousand stamps, then three red hundred stamps, four blue ten stamps, and five little green one stamps. See? We are making a big number with tiny pieces!

slides.text: 'Each stamp represents one bead. This blue 10 stamp is like one golden ten bar. But stamps are quicker to work with!'
slides.mascot_explanation: These little stamps are like magic! Each stamp is like one golden bead, so a blue stamp with '10' on it is just like one golden ten bar. Using stamps makes it super fast to build big numbers!

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with stamps: 1,234. Then 3,671. Then 4,508. Then choose your own big number and build it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to play! Can you build the number 1,234 with the stamps, and then 3,671? After that, try building 4,508, and then pick your very own big number to make! You can do it!

slides.text: 'The stamp game is a powerful tool! Next time we will use it to add and subtract, just like we did with golden beads.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly build any 4-digit number using the stamp game stamps?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job with the stamp game today! You learned how to use the tiny stamps to build big numbers, just like we did with the golden beads. Next time, we'll use these stamps to do even more math fun!

parent_notes: The stamp game is a critical bridge material in Montessori math. It moves the child from the concrete golden beads (where 10 is physically 10 beads on a bar) to a more abstract representation (where 10 is a single stamp marked '10'). This is one step closer to pencil-and-paper arithmetic. The color coding is essential: it matches the Montessori color hierarchy (green=units, blue=tens, red=hundreds, green=thousands) which the child already knows from numeral cards. Children who have worked extensively with golden beads typically transition to the stamp game smoothly because the operations are identical — only the material has changed. Let the child compare: lay a golden ten bar next to a blue 10 stamp.

title: Community Helpers — Doctors and Nurses
description: Exploring the roles of doctors and nurses in our community. The child learns about the tools they use, how they help people, and practices a simple doctor visit role play.
instructions:
1. 'Who do we visit when we are sick or need a checkup? Doctors and nurses!'
2. Show pictures of doctors and nurses at work.
3. Introduce tools: stethoscope, thermometer, bandages, blood pressure cuff.
4. 'Doctors figure out what is wrong — they DIAGNOSE. Nurses help take care of you — they TREAT.'
5. Role play: set up a pretend doctor's office. Child is the doctor.
6. 'Check the patient (stuffed animal). Listen to the heart, take temperature, apply a bandage.'
7. Discuss: 'How do doctors and nurses help our community?'

slides.heading: Community Helpers
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Community Helpers," and we're going to learn all about doctors and nurses today! They are super important people who help us when we don't feel well.

items: Optional: white shirt as lab coat
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a pretend doctor's office with a chair for the patient (stuffed animal) and medical tools laid out on a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our pretend doctor's office! We have pictures to see, a special toy doctor kit with tools, and a fluffy friend who will be our patient. Maybe you can even wear a white shirt like a real doctor's coat!

slides.text: 'Today we learn about doctors and nurses — people who help us stay healthy! Have you visited a doctor? What happened?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's talk about doctors and nurses! Do you remember when you went to the doctor? They help us feel better when we have a boo-boo or a cough.

slides.text: 'Doctors and nurses use special TOOLS.' Show the stethoscope: 'This listens to your heart and lungs.' Thermometer: 'This checks your temperature.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these cool tools? This one is a stethoscope, and it helps us listen to our hearts go thump-thump! This other one is a thermometer, and it tells us if we have a fever, like when we feel extra warm.

slides.text: 'Doctors go to school for a very long time to learn how the body works. Nurses learn to care for patients and help them feel better.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Doctors and nurses are very smart! They go to school to learn all about how our bodies work and how to make us feel all better. Nurses are extra good at taking care of us and giving us hugs when we're sad.

slides.text: 'Now YOU be the doctor! Your patient (stuffed animal) has a sore tummy. What will you do? Listen with the stethoscope, take temperature, prescribe rest!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the doctor! Your teddy bear has a tummy ache, so you need to be a super detective. You can use your pretend tools to figure out what's wrong and help them feel better.

slides.prompt: Set up your doctor's office. Examine your patient. Use each tool. Write a 'prescription' for your patient: rest, water, soup. Take care of your patient!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play doctor! You get to use all your tools on your stuffed animal patient, just like a real doctor. You can even pretend to give them a prescription for lots of rest and yummy soup!

slides.text: 'Doctors and nurses keep our whole community healthy. They are helpers we can always count on!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 medical tools and explain how doctors and nurses help people?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a doctor today! Doctors and nurses are amazing helpers who keep everyone in our town healthy and happy. You are a wonderful helper too!

parent_notes: Community helpers is a Montessori cultural studies topic that builds social awareness and gratitude. When studying doctors and nurses, connect to the child's own experiences — checkups, vaccinations, visits for illness. This normalizes medical visits and reduces anxiety. The role play is particularly valuable: when a child plays 'doctor,' they process their experiences and gain a sense of mastery over something that can feel scary. Use accurate vocabulary: stethoscope, thermometer, diagnosis, treatment. Children are capable of learning real terminology. If possible, visit a pediatrician's office or invite a medical professional to share about their work.

title: Read-Aloud: Curious George Goes to the Hospital
description: Curious George visits the hospital after swallowing a puzzle piece. This story connects to the community helpers theme and helps demystify hospital visits for young children.
instructions:
1. 'Today George goes to the hospital! Have you ever been to a hospital?'
2. Read aloud with expression.
3. Pause when George meets the doctor: 'What tools is the doctor using? We learned about those!'
4. Discuss: 'How did the doctors and nurses help George?'
5. 'George was brave. It is okay to feel scared at the hospital, but the helpers there want to take care of you.'
6. Draw a picture of George at the hospital or design a get-well card.
materials_needed: Curious George Goes to the Hospital by H.A. Rey and Margret Rey

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Curious George Goes to the Hospital
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this picture! It tells us the name of our special story today. We're going to read about Curious George and his trip to the hospital. Isn't that exciting?

items: Curious George Goes to the Hospital book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Prepare drawing supplies for the response activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our activity! We have a book with a monkey on it, and some colorful papers and crayons. These are the things we'll use to make something special after our story.

slides.text: 'George is curious as always — and this time his curiosity leads him to the hospital! Let us find out what happens.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our story is starting! We're going to read about George, who is always so curious, and he's going to the hospital. Let's turn the page together and see what happens to him!

slides.text: Read aloud. When George meets the doctor: 'Look! The doctor is using a stethoscope — just like the one we played with today!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read the story! When George meets the doctor, look closely. The doctor is using a special tool to listen to George's heart, just like the one we saw before!

slides.text: After reading: 'George swallowed a puzzle piece! That is why we never put small things in our mouths. How did the hospital help him?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no! George swallowed a puzzle piece! That's why we always keep small toys out of our mouths, right? Let's think about how the doctors and nurses helped make George feel all better.

slides.prompt: Make a get-well card for someone — it could be for George, a friend, or a family member. Draw a picture and write a message if you can.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be helpers! We're going to make a "get well" card. We can draw a nice picture for George, or for someone else who needs a smile. Let's use our crayons and paper to make it super special!

slides.text: 'Hospitals are places where people go to get better. Doctors and nurses are there to help, just like they helped George.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell what happened to George and identify how the medical professionals helped?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned so much today! Hospitals are places where people go to get better, and doctors and nurses are like superheroes who help us. George was very brave at the hospital, and now he's all better!

parent_notes: This read-aloud pairs perfectly with the community helpers lesson on doctors and nurses. Curious George books are gentle enough for young children while addressing real-life situations. The hospital setting may bring up questions or anxieties — welcome them. Reassure the child that hospitals are safe places with helpers. Making a get-well card extends the theme into practical kindness and is a meaningful writing opportunity. If your child has had a hospital experience, let them share — processing through storytelling is healthy. The H.A. Rey version is the classic, but updated editions are also available.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
