Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Constructive Triangles — Third Box (Rectangles)
description: Using the third box of constructive triangles, the child discovers that rectangles of different proportions can all be built from two right-angled triangles. This deepens understanding of geometric relationships.
instructions:
1. Present the third box of constructive triangles.
2. 'We have built shapes with triangles before. Today we discover something about RECTANGLES.'
3. Remove a pair of matching right triangles. Show how they form a rectangle when the black lines are matched.
4. 'Two triangles make a rectangle!' Build all the rectangles in the box.
5. 'Are all the rectangles the same? No — some are long and thin, some are short and wide.'
6. Grade the rectangles from widest to narrowest.
7. Child rebuilds all pairs independently.

slides.heading: Constructive Triangles
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special box of triangles that help us make something new today. We are going to learn all about building rectangles!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the third box on the work mat. Ensure all pieces are present and the black lines are visible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special tools for our building game! We have our box of triangles, and this is our special mat to build on. Can you help find these for our activity?

slides.text: 'Remember how we built squares and other shapes from triangles? Today we use this box to build RECTANGLES.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we played with triangles before? Today, we're going to use them in a super fun way to discover how to make rectangles, just like doors or windows!

slides.text: Take out one pair of matching right triangles. 'Match the black lines together...' Push them together. 'A rectangle! Two triangles always make a rectangle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let’s take out two triangles that match. See their black lines? If we put those lines together, poof! We made a rectangle! Two triangles make one rectangle!

slides.text: 'Now find the next pair. Match their black lines.' Continue building all rectangles. 'How many rectangles did we make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s find another pair of triangles, just like the last ones. Match their black lines and see what shape we make this time! How many different rectangles can we build together?

slides.text: 'Look at all our rectangles. Are they the same? This one is wide, this one is narrow. But they are ALL rectangles — four sides, four corners.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the rectangles we made! Some are fat and some are skinny, but they are all rectangles with four sides and four corners. It's like a big rectangle family!

slides.prompt: Build all the rectangles from the box. Then put them in order from widest to narrowest. Can you build them without looking at the black lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s your turn to be the builder! Can you put all the triangles together to make each rectangle, and then line them up from the fattest to the skinniest? You can do it!

slides.text: 'Every rectangle can be divided into two triangles. Triangles are the building blocks of many shapes!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child construct all rectangles from triangles and grade them by width?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building and sorting all those rectangles! Remember, every rectangle is made of two triangles, like magic building blocks for shapes!

parent_notes: The constructive triangles are among the most elegant Montessori sensorial materials. The third box focuses specifically on rectangles — all built from pairs of right triangles. The key insight is that ANY rectangle can be divided into two right triangles along its diagonal. This is a foundation for later geometry (area of a triangle = half the area of a rectangle). The black lines guide the child at first, but the real learning happens when they can construct without the guide — recognizing which pairs go together by shape and size. Grading the rectangles from wide to narrow is a sensorial exercise in proportion. Some children enjoy tracing the completed rectangles on paper.

title: Reading Short Books — First Phonetic Readers
description: The child reads their first simple phonetic books independently. These small books contain CVC words, blends, and the phonograms they have learned, giving the child the thrill of reading a whole book.
instructions:
1. 'You have been reading words and sentences. Today you will read a WHOLE BOOK!'
2. Present a simple phonetic reader (3-6 pages, 1-2 sentences per page).
3. 'Look at the cover. What do you think this book is about?'
4. Child reads page by page. Help only if they ask or are stuck for more than 10 seconds.
5. For unknown words: 'Sound it out. What does this phonogram say?'
6. Celebrate completing the book! 'You read a whole book by yourself!'
7. Offer a second book if the child wants to continue.
materials_needed: Phonetic readers (Bob Books, Primary Phonics, or similar)
Reading mat or special reading spot

slides.heading: Reading Short Books
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We get to read some special books today, and they are all for YOU to read all by yourself! Isn't that exciting?

slides.setup_instructions: Choose books that use CVC words, simple blends, and phonograms the child knows (sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo). Set up a cozy reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few things for our reading fun! See these little books? They have words we know how to sound out. We also need a cozy spot to sit, and a special marker to help us remember where we stopped. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these?

slides.text: 'You have learned so many sounds, phonograms, and words. You are READY to read a real book! Here is your first one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know so many letter sounds and word parts now, like 'c-a-t' and 'sh'! Because you are so smart, you get to read a whole book using all those sounds. This book is just for you!

slides.text: Show the cover. 'What do you see? What do you think will happen? Let us open it and find out!' Child reads the title.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at the front of our book. What pictures do you see here? What do you think this story might be about? Let's turn the page and start reading!

slides.text: Child reads each page aloud. If stuck: 'Sound it out slowly. What does each part say?' Give time — do not jump in too quickly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's read each page together. If you see a word that's a little tricky, let's sound it out slowly, like "b-u-s." Take your time, you can do it!

slides.text: After finishing: 'You read a WHOLE BOOK! How does that feel? What was your favorite part?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You read a whole book all by yourself! How does it feel to be a reader? What was your very favorite part of the story?

slides.prompt: Read the book again — the second time is even easier! Then try the next book. You are a reader now!
slides.mascot_explanation: Reading a book is so much fun, we can even read it again! Or, if you want, we can pick out another book to read together. You are a super reader now!

slides.text: 'You are officially a book reader! Every great reader started with a small book just like this one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently read a simple phonetic reader with minimal assistance?
slides.mascot_explanation: You know what? You are a real reader now! You read a whole book with your own eyes and your own smart brain. Just like all the best readers, you started with a book like this one!

parent_notes: Reading a first book independently is one of the most transformative moments in a child's education. Choose books carefully — they should be decodable using the phonics the child has learned, not relying on pictures or guessing. Bob Books, Primary Phonics, and Montessori-aligned readers work well. The child may read slowly, letter by letter — this is normal and correct. Do NOT rush them or finish words for them. The struggle of sounding out IS the learning. If they get stuck, point to the letters and ask, 'What sound does this make?' After reading, celebrate genuinely. Many children want to read their first book over and over — encourage this! Rereading builds fluency and confidence. This is a milestone worth marking — consider a small certificate or letting the child call a grandparent to read aloud over the phone.

title: Stamp Game — Addition
description: The child uses the stamp game to perform addition with exchange, transferring the golden bead concepts to this more abstract material. The process is identical but uses stamps instead of beads.
instructions:
1. 'Let us add with the stamp game, just like we added with golden beads!'
2. Problem: 1,234 + 2,458.
3. 'Build the first number with stamps: 1 thousand, 2 hundreds, 3 tens, 4 units.'
4. 'Build the second number below it: 2 thousands, 4 hundreds, 5 tens, 8 units.'
5. 'Combine — start with units: 4 + 8 = 12. Exchange 10 unit stamps for 1 ten stamp!'
6. Continue combining tens, hundreds, thousands — exchanging as needed.
7. Read the answer: 3,692. Practice with 2-3 more problems.
materials_needed: Problem cards or paper with addition problems

slides.heading: Stamp Game Addition
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Stamp Game Addition," and that means we're going to do some super-duper adding, just like we did before, but with special stamps! We'll learn how to "exchange" when we have too many of one kind of stamp, which is a big kid math skill!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the stamp game on the mat. Prepare 3-4 addition problems with 4-digit numbers that require exchanging.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our math adventure! We have the colorful stamp game, a mat to keep our work tidy, some cards with numbers on them, and a pencil. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these special tools so we can get started with our adding fun!

slides.text: 'Remember how we added with golden beads and exchanged? The stamp game works the same way! Let us add 1,234 + 2,458.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we used the shiny golden beads to add big numbers? Well, this stamp game is just like that, but with stamps! Today, we're going to add two big numbers together: 1,234 and 2,458. It's like a math puzzle we get to solve!

slides.text: 'Build 1,234 in the top row: 1 green thousand stamp, 2 red hundred stamps, 3 blue ten stamps, 4 green unit stamps.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's build the first number with our stamps. We need one big thousand stamp, two red hundred stamps, three blue ten stamps, and four little green unit stamps to make 1,234. Put them all in a neat row on your mat, just like we practiced!

slides.text: 'Build 2,458 below: 2 thousand stamps, 4 hundred stamps, 5 ten stamps, 8 unit stamps. Now COMBINE! Start with units: 4 + 8 = 12.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job building the first number! Now, let's build the second number right below it: two thousand stamps, four hundred stamps, five ten stamps, and eight unit stamps for 2,458. After that, we'll push them all together, starting with the little unit stamps – 4 plus 8 makes 12!

slides.text: '12 units! Exchange 10 unit stamps for 1 ten stamp. That leaves 2 units. Move to tens: 3 + 5 + 1 (from exchange) = 9 tens.' Continue through hundreds and thousands.
slides.mascot_explanation: We have 12 unit stamps, but we can only have 9 of each kind at the bottom! So, we'll swap 10 of our unit stamps for one shiny ten stamp. Now we have 2 units left, and we can add the ten stamps together. We'll keep doing this for hundreds and thousands too!

slides.prompt: Try these: 2,356 + 1,487. Then 3,275 + 4,638. Build, combine, exchange, and find each answer!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the math superstar! We have two new number puzzles for you: 2,356 + 1,487 and then 3,275 + 4,638. You get to build them, push them together, and do all the exciting exchanging to find the answers all by yourself!

slides.text: 'You added big numbers with the stamp game! The stamps are just like golden beads but faster to work with.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 4-digit addition with exchange using the stamp game?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You added really big numbers using the stamp game and learned all about exchanging, just like a math whiz! Those stamps helped us add super fast, and you were amazing at figuring out how to swap them. You're getting so good at math!

parent_notes: The stamp game addition process is identical to golden bead addition — the child builds two numbers, combines them starting with units, and exchanges when any category reaches 10 or more. The difference is that stamps are more abstract: a single stamp marked '10' replaces a physical ten-bar of 10 connected beads. If the child struggles, go back to golden beads for that problem and then retry with stamps. The key transition is understanding that one stamp can represent a quantity. Most children who have done extensive golden bead work find the stamp game intuitive. Always start combining from units and work left — this mirrors the standard algorithm they will learn later.

title: Five Classes of Vertebrates
description: Building on the vertebrate/invertebrate lesson, the child learns the five classes of vertebrates: fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. Each class has unique characteristics.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Vertebrates have backbones. Today we learn the FIVE groups of vertebrates.'
2. Present each class with picture cards and a key characteristic:
   - Fish: live in water, breathe with gills, have scales
   - Amphibians: live in water AND land, moist skin, start as tadpoles
   - Reptiles: have dry, scaly skin, lay eggs on land
   - Birds: have feathers, lay eggs, most can fly
   - Mammals: have hair/fur, mothers make milk, born alive (mostly)
3. Sing or chant the five classes.
4. Sort animal cards into five groups.
materials_needed: Animal picture cards (3 per class, 15 total)
Chart or poster of vertebrate classes

slides.heading: Five Classes of Vertebrates
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this colorful slide! It tells us we're going to learn about five special groups of animals that have something called a backbone, which is like a strong support inside them. We'll learn about fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare labels for each class. Gather 3+ picture cards per class. Lay out on a large mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have lots of fun animal pictures to play with today! We also have special signs for each animal group, and a big chart to help us. Let's get all these animal pictures and signs ready on the mat so we can start sorting!

slides.text: 'Vertebrates are sorted into five groups. Each group has something special.' Hold up a fish picture. 'FISH live in water and breathe with GILLS instead of lungs.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first animal is a fish! See? Fish live in the water, and they breathe with special things called gills, not like us with noses. We're learning that fish are one of our five special animal groups.

slides.text: 'AMPHIBIANS start in water as babies (like tadpoles) and move to land as adults. Frogs and salamanders are amphibians. Their skin is moist!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we have amphibians! These animals are super cool because they can live in the water when they are little babies, and then they grow up to live on the land too! They have soft, wet skin, like a froggy!

slides.text: 'REPTILES have dry, scaly skin. Snakes, lizards, turtles — all reptiles! BIRDS have FEATHERS — they are the only animals with feathers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at these two groups! Reptiles have dry, scaly skin, like a snake or a turtle. And birds are the only animals that have feathers, which help them fly! Isn't that neat?

slides.text: 'MAMMALS have hair or fur, and mothers make MILK for their babies. Dogs, cats, whales, and YOU — all mammals!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This last group is mammals, and guess what? We are mammals too! Mammals have hair or fur, and the mommies make yummy milk to feed their babies. That's how they grow big and strong!

slides.prompt: Sort the animal cards into five groups. For each card ask: Does it have gills? Moist skin? Scales? Feathers? Fur? That tells you which group!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to play a sorting game! We'll look at each animal picture and decide if it's a fish, amphibian, reptile, bird, or mammal. We can look at their skin, or if they have feathers, to help us figure it out!

slides.text: 'Fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals — five classes of vertebrates! Can you name one animal in each class?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the five vertebrate classes and correctly sort at least 12 of 15 animal cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned about all five groups of animals with backbones: fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals! You did such a great job sorting all the animals! Can you tell me one animal from each group?

parent_notes: The five vertebrate classes are a cornerstone of Montessori zoology. The key characteristics to emphasize are: fish (gills, scales, aquatic), amphibians (moist skin, metamorphosis, water/land), reptiles (dry scales, eggs on land), birds (feathers, eggs), mammals (hair/fur, milk, live birth). Some children ask about exceptions — whales are mammals despite living in water, platypuses are mammals that lay eggs. Welcome these questions as signs of critical thinking! A simple chant helps memory: 'Fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals — five classes, five classes!' This work connects to the Great Lessons in later Montessori years (the Coming of Life).

title: Music — Complex Rhythm Patterns with Instruments
description: Exploring complex rhythm patterns with classroom instruments including syncopation, layered rhythms, and call-and-response patterns.
instructions:
1. 'Music has a BEAT — like a heartbeat! Let us find it.' Clap a steady beat together.
2. Introduce instruments: tambourine, rhythm sticks, shaker, triangle.
3. Demonstrate a simple pattern: clap-clap-shake, clap-clap-shake.
4. Child echoes the pattern.
5. Introduce pattern notation: large circle = loud/strong beat, small circle = soft beat.
6. Read a rhythm pattern from the cards. Play it with instruments.
7. Child creates their own pattern. Perform it for you.
materials_needed: Paper and crayons for creating patterns

slides.heading: Music
slides.subheading: Music — Complex Rhythm Patterns with Instruments
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! We're going to have so much fun making music today! We'll learn about beats and play with cool instruments.

items: Percussion instruments: tambourine, rhythm sticks, shaker, triangle
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out instruments on a mat. Prepare 4-5 rhythm pattern cards with large and small circles representing strong and soft beats.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we get to play with! We have a tambourine that goes jingle-jingle, sticks that go click-click, a shaker that goes shh-shh, and a triangle that goes ding! We also have some cards with circles on them and paper and crayons for drawing. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Put your hand on your chest. Feel your heartbeat? That is a steady BEAT! Music has a beat too.' Clap together: 1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's feel our own special beat! Put your hand on your chest and feel your heart going thump-thump. That's like a steady beat! Music has a beat too, and we can clap it together, nice and steady like this: 1, 2, 3, 4.

slides.text: 'These instruments make different sounds.' Try each: tambourine (jingle), sticks (click), shaker (shh), triangle (ding). 'Which is your favorite?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's listen to our instruments! This one is a tambourine, and it makes a jingly sound. These are rhythm sticks, and they go click! This is a shaker, and it makes a soft sound. And this is a triangle, which makes a pretty ding! Which sound do you like the best?

slides.text: 'I will play a pattern. Listen, then copy me!' Play: TAP-TAP-shake, TAP-TAP-shake. Child echoes.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's like playing a game! I'm going to make a sound pattern with my hands and instruments, and then you get to copy me! Listen carefully: TAP-TAP-shake, TAP-TAP-shake. Now you try!

slides.text: 'Look at this card. Big circle means STRONG beat, small circle means soft beat.' Read and play a card pattern together.
slides.mascot_explanation: These cards have circles on them, like little drawings. A big circle means we play loud and strong, like a big drum! A small circle means we play soft and gentle, like a whisper. Let's look at a card together and play the pattern with our instruments!

slides.prompt: Create your own rhythm pattern! Draw big and small circles on paper. Then play your pattern with an instrument. Perform it for me!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you are going to make your very own music! On your paper, draw some big circles and some small circles to make your own secret rhythm. Then, pick an instrument and play your special pattern for me! You can do it!

slides.text: Perform each other's rhythm patterns. 'You are a rhythm composer! Put your instruments away carefully — each one has its own spot.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child maintain a steady beat, echo a rhythm pattern, and create their own simple pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were amazing at making music! We clapped the beat, played the patterns, and you even made up your own rhythm! Now, let's carefully put our instruments back in their special spots. You are a super music composer!

parent_notes: Rhythm is the foundation of music education in Montessori. Before melody or harmony, children need to feel and reproduce steady beats and patterns. Echo games (adult plays, child copies) develop auditory memory and motor coordination. The pattern notation with circles is a pre-reading activity for musical notation — the child reads symbols that represent sounds, just as letters represent speech sounds. Let the child explore the instruments freely before structured work. Each instrument has its own technique: hold the triangle by its string, shake the maraca from the wrist, tap rhythm sticks with a bouncing motion. Creating their own patterns gives ownership and creativity within a structured framework.
household_substitutes: Pots, pans, wooden spoons for rhythm
preparation_steps: Gather sound-making objects. Choose a space where noise is okay.
control_of_error: Can the child repeat a rhythm pattern? Can they keep a steady beat?
extension_ideas: Create a simple song together
Clap rhythm patterns for each other to copy
Listen to different genres and compare

title: Cooking Project — Fruit Salad
description: The child prepares a fruit salad using multiple fruits, practicing cutting, measuring, and following a recipe. This more complex cooking project builds on the trail mix experience.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Review the recipe card together: 3 fruits, cut and combined.
2. Wash all fruits. Name each: strawberries, banana, grapes (or seasonal alternatives).
3. Demonstrate hulling a strawberry and cutting into slices.
4. Child cuts strawberries. Then banana (review from earlier lessons).
5. Child halves grapes (adult pre-cuts if needed for safety).
6. Combine all fruit in a bowl. Stir gently with a spoon.
7. Serve in small cups. Clean up all tools and workspace.
materials_needed: 3 types of fruit (strawberries, banana, grapes or seasonal)

slides.heading: Cooking Project
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make something super yummy today called fruit salad! It's like a special treat we get to make all by ourselves.

slides.setup_instructions: Wash all fruit. Lay out on a tray with cutting board, knife, bowl, and spoon. Have the recipe card visible.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our yummy fruit salad, we need some special things! We need three different kinds of fruit, a safe knife for cutting, a cutting board, a big bowl, some little cups, a spoon, and a recipe card to help us. Can you help ask a grown-up to find all these things for our cooking adventure?

slides.text: 'Today we are making fruit salad! We need to cut three different fruits and combine them. Let us read the recipe first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is so exciting because we get to make fruit salad! We'll get to chop up yummy fruits and mix them all together. First, let's look at our special recipe card together to see what we need to do.

slides.text: Demonstrate with a strawberry: 'First, remove the green top — this is called HULLING. Then slice it into pieces.' Show slow, controlled cutting.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this red strawberry? We need to take off its green hat, like we're giving it a little haircut! Then, we'll carefully slice it into little pieces, just like this.

slides.text: 'Your turn! Hull the strawberries and slice them. When you are done, we will cut the banana — you already know how to do that!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the chef! First, take off the green tops from the strawberries, and then slice them up. After that, we'll cut the banana, which you're already a super star at doing!

slides.text: 'For the grapes, we cut them in half. Hold the grape on the board and cut straight down the middle.' Demonstrate. Child halves grapes.
slides.mascot_explanation: For the little round grapes, we need to cut them right in half. Hold the grape still on the board and make a careful cut right down the middle. It's like giving them a little smile!

slides.prompt: Cut all the remaining fruit. Put everything into the bowl and stir gently. Scoop fruit salad into serving cups. Enjoy!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the best part! Let's put all our yummy cut-up fruits into the big bowl. We'll give it a gentle stir with our spoon, and then scoop our amazing fruit salad into these little cups. Time to taste our delicious creation!

slides.text: Clean up: wash the cutting board, knife, bowl, and spoon. Wipe the table. Compost scraps. 'You made a real recipe from start to finish!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently prepare a multi-fruit salad following the recipe card with safe cutting technique?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You made a real fruit salad recipe all by yourself, from start to finish! You were so good at cutting all the fruits safely and mixing everything up. What a super chef you are!

parent_notes: Fruit salad involves more cutting variety than previous recipes: hulling strawberries, slicing bananas (review), and halving grapes (new skill). Grape halving is particularly important for safety awareness — whole grapes are a choking hazard for younger siblings, so the child learns a practical safety skill. Let the child choose which fruits to include if possible — agency increases engagement. The recipe card should show each step with pictures. This recipe has no cooking, so the child can truly do every step independently. Fruit salad is also a wonderful math connection: 'If we have 6 strawberries and each gets cut into 4 pieces, how many pieces?'
household_substitutes: Ingredients as listed in the lesson
preparation_steps: Wash hands first. Set out all ingredients and tools before calling the child. Pre-wash produce.
control_of_error: The finished food item shows the result. Taste-testing is the best self-check!
extension_ideas: Let the child serve the food to family
Draw or write about what you made
Try a variation with different ingredients

title: Phonogram Review and Word Building
description: Review of all four phonograms learned this week (ai, oa, ee, oo) plus puzzle words (the, a, is, was). The child builds and reads words and sentences combining phonograms and puzzle words.
instructions:
1. 'Let us review our phonograms! What sound do these make?' Flash ai, oa, ee, oo cards.
2. Speed round: show a card, child says the sound.
3. Build words with each phonogram: rain, boat, tree, moon.
4. Add puzzle words: 'Can you read these sentences?'
5. Sentence strips: 'The rain is wet.' 'A boat was on the sea.' 'The tree is green.'
6. Child builds their own sentence with moveable alphabet using phonograms and puzzle words.
7. Read the sentence aloud.
materials_needed: Phonogram cards (ai, oa, ee, oo, sh, ch, th)
Puzzle word cards (the, a, is, was)

slides.heading: Phonogram Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun page! We're going to learn about special word sounds and put them together to make whole sentences, just like building with blocks!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all phonogram cards and puzzle word cards. Prepare sentence strips. Have moveable alphabet ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have lots of fun things to play with today! We have special cards with sounds, letter pieces to build words, and strips with sentences already made. Let's get all these ready so we can start our word adventure!

slides.text: 'This week you learned four new phonograms. Let us see if you remember!' Hold up ai: 'What does this say?' Repeat for oa, ee, oo.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see if you remember those special sounds we learned! Watch me show you a card, and you tell me the sound it makes – like magic!

slides.text: 'Excellent! Now let us read words.' Show word cards one at a time: rain, coat, seed, food, trail, groan, teeth, spoon.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read some super cool words using those sounds! I'll show you a word, and you tell me what it says. You're going to be a word detective!

slides.text: 'Now combine with puzzle words! Read this sentence.' Show: 'The rain is on the road.' Child reads each word.
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job reading those words! Now, let's try reading a whole sentence. See if you can read all the words on this sentence strip, just like we practiced.

slides.text: 'Read more!' Show: 'A bee was in the tree.' 'The moon is big.' Celebrate smooth reading!
slides.mascot_explanation: You are doing so awesome reading! Let's try these next two sentences. Read each word slowly and carefully, and I bet you'll read them perfectly!

slides.prompt: Build your own sentence with the moveable alphabet. Use at least one phonogram word and one puzzle word. Then read it to me!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the boss of the words! Use your letter pieces to make your very own sentence with a special sound word and a puzzle word, then read it to me!

slides.text: 'You can read phonograms, puzzle words, AND sentences! You are reading so well. Keep practicing with your books!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read sentences containing phonogram words and puzzle words fluently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are such a super reader, sounding out words and reading whole sentences all by yourself. Keep practicing your reading, and you'll be a reading star!

parent_notes: Friday review is essential for consolidation. The child has learned a lot this week: four phonograms and four puzzle words. The review should feel like a celebration of what they have learned, not a test. If the child hesitates on a phonogram, simply remind them and move on — it will solidify with more exposure. The sentence-building activity is powerful because the child becomes an AUTHOR: they choose the words, construct the meaning, and read their creation. This is writing in its truest sense, even though the child is using moveable alphabet rather than pencil. Save any sentences the child builds — photograph them or transcribe them into a special book.

title: Stamp Game — Subtraction
description: The child uses the stamp game for subtraction with exchange. When there are not enough stamps in a category, the child learns to exchange one stamp from the next higher category for 10 of the current category.
instructions:
1. 'We can subtract with the stamp game too! Let us try 3,542 - 1,267.'
2. Build 3,542 with stamps.
3. 'Start with units: take away 7. But we only have 2! We need to EXCHANGE.'
4. Exchange 1 ten stamp for 10 unit stamps. Now we have 12 units. Take away 7 = 5.
5. Tens: 3 tens (after exchange) - 6 tens. Exchange again from hundreds.
6. Continue through hundreds and thousands.
7. Read the answer: 2,275. Practice with more problems.

slides.heading: Stamp Game Subtraction
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is our special math game! It's called Stamp Game Subtraction, and we're going to learn how to take numbers away, even when we need to do a little trading. It's going to be super fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the stamp game on the mat. Prepare subtraction problems that require exchanging.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our game! We have the colorful stamp game pieces, a mat to work on, cards with our math problems, and a pencil. Ask your grown-up to help you find them all so we can play!

slides.text: 'Addition combines. Subtraction takes away! Let us subtract 1,267 from 3,542. First, build 3,542.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we get to build a big number with our stamps: 3,542. We have lots of stamps for thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones, so let's put them on our mat to make that number. We're going to use these stamps to take some away!

slides.text: 'Start with units: take away 7. Count your unit stamps — only 2! We need more. EXCHANGE: trade 1 ten stamp for 10 unit stamps.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we need to take away 7 little ones, but oh no, we only have 2! Don't worry, we can trade. We'll swap one of our 'ten' stamps for ten 'one' stamps. See? Now we have enough ones to take away!

slides.text: 'Now you have 12 unit stamps. Take away 7.' Child removes 7 units. '5 units remain. Move to tens: you now have 3 tens. Take away 6. Not enough!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job! We took away 7 ones, and we have 5 left. Now we need to take away 6 tens, but we only have 3 left after our trade. Uh oh, we need to trade again! We'll swap a 'hundred' stamp for ten 'ten' stamps.

slides.text: 'Exchange 1 hundred stamp for 10 ten stamps. Now 13 tens, take away 6 = 7 tens. Continue: hundreds, thousands.' Arrive at 2,275.
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! Now we have 13 tens, and we can take away 6, leaving 7 tens. We'll keep going with the hundreds and thousands just like we did, trading when we need to. You're doing so well!

slides.prompt: Try 4,731 - 2,548. Build the first number. Subtract starting from units, exchanging when needed. Check: does your answer make sense?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try a new number! We need to take 2,548 away from 4,731. Build the first number with your stamps, and then try taking away the smaller number, remembering to trade when you need to. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Subtraction with exchange is like the reverse of addition with exchange. You are doing really advanced math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 4-digit subtraction with exchange using the stamp game?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a math superstar! You learned how to take numbers away and trade stamps, just like a super smart grown-up. That's like doing math backward and forward, and you did it perfectly!

parent_notes: Stamp game subtraction with exchange (borrowing) is one of the most important Montessori math lessons. The physical act of trading one ten stamp for 10 unit stamps makes 'borrowing' concrete and logical. The child literally sees that 1 ten equals 10 units — there is nothing mysterious about it. Always start subtracting from units (right to left). If the child forgets to exchange, they will discover they do not have enough stamps — this self-correcting aspect is built into the material. Do not explain the algorithm abstractly; let the hands teach the brain. After many repetitions with the stamp game, the child will eventually be ready for pencil-and-paper subtraction and will already understand what 'borrowing' means.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Telephone Manners
description: The child learns proper telephone manners: how to answer a phone, take a message, make a polite call, and say goodbye. Role play with a toy phone makes this practical and fun.
instructions:
1. 'Telephones help us talk to people far away. Let us learn how to use one politely.'
2. Demonstrate answering: 'Hello, this is the [family name] home. May I ask who is calling?'
3. Demonstrate calling: 'Hello, this is [child name]. May I please speak to [person]?'
4. Practice taking a message: 'They are not here right now. May I take a message?'
5. Role play: you call, child answers. Then switch.
6. Practice leaving a message: name, reason for calling, phone number.
7. 'Always say goodbye and wait for the other person to say goodbye too.'
materials_needed: Two toy phones or old cell phones

slides.heading: Grace and Courtesy
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun topic! We're going to learn about being polite and using the telephone, like when we talk to Grandma on the phone. It's like learning special manners for talking to people far away!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up two phones on opposite sides of a table. Have a message pad and pencil ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some fun toys to play with today! We have two pretend phones so we can talk to each other, a little notepad and pencil for writing messages, and some cards to help us remember what to say. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready for our game!

slides.text: 'When the phone rings, we answer politely.' Demonstrate: 'Hello, this is the Smith home. Who is calling please?' Practice three times.
slides.mascot_explanation: When the phone rings, it's important to say "Hello!" nicely. We'll pretend to answer the phone and say who we are, like "Hello, this is our house!" Then we ask who is calling, just like a super polite grown-up. Let's practice saying hello three times!

slides.text: 'When YOU call someone, say your name first.' Demonstrate: 'Hello, this is Ana. May I please speak to Grandma?' Practice.
slides.mascot_explanation: When you want to talk to someone, like your friend, you need to tell them who you are first. So you'll say, "Hello, this is [Your Name]!" Then you can ask to talk to the person you want to, like "May I please talk to [Friend's Name]?" We'll practice this so you sound super friendly!

slides.text: 'Sometimes the person is not home. Then you take a MESSAGE.' Write on the pad: who called, what they said, phone number.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, the person you want to talk to isn't there. That's okay! We can be helpers and take a message for them. We'll write down who called, what they wanted to say, and their phone number so they can call back. It's like being a little secretary!

slides.text: 'Always say GOODBYE before hanging up. And use a kind voice — the person cannot see your face, so your voice shows your feelings.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we finish talking, it's super important to say "goodbye" nicely. We need to use a kind voice because the other person can't see your smile! We say goodbye and wait for them to say goodbye too before we hang up.

slides.prompt: Let us role play! I will call and you answer. Then you call me. Take a message when I am not available. Practice until it feels natural!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for our super fun phone game! I'll pretend to call you, and you answer like we practiced. Then, you can pretend to call me! If I'm not home, you can practice taking a message for me. We'll keep playing until it feels like magic!

slides.text: 'Now you know how to answer, call, take a message, and say goodbye on the phone. Practice with a real call to a family member this week!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer the phone politely, make a call, and take a simple message?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You are now a telephone expert! You know how to answer the phone, call someone, and even take a message. This week, let's try calling a real grown-up, like Grandma or Grandpa, and use your new telephone manners!

parent_notes: Telephone manners is a classic Montessori grace and courtesy lesson that remains relevant even in the age of texting. The child learns social scripts that reduce anxiety about phone calls and build confidence in communication. Role play is essential — the child needs to practice both sides of the conversation multiple times. Using real (but deactivated) phones makes the practice more authentic than toy phones. After practicing, arrange for the child to make a real call to a grandparent or friend — the transfer from practice to real life is thrilling for the child. Taking a message also involves writing practice: who called, what they said, their number. This is a practical, real-world reason to write.
household_substitutes: No materials needed — this is a role-play and discussion lesson
preparation_steps: Think of scenarios to role-play. Keep it playful and positive.
control_of_error: Practice in real situations throughout the day.
extension_ideas: Role-play at a pretend restaurant
Write thank-you notes
Practice with stuffed animals or dolls

title: Read-Aloud: Strega Nona by Tomie dePaola
description: A beloved Italian folktale about a magic pasta pot and what happens when Big Anthony does not follow the rules. Themes of listening, responsibility, and consequences connect to practical life.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This story comes from Italy — remember Italy on our Europe map? It looked like a boot!'
2. 'Strega Nona means Grandma Witch in Italian. She has a magic pasta pot!'
3. Read aloud with expression. Pause when Big Anthony discovers the magic words.
4. 'What do you think will happen when Big Anthony uses the pot?' Predict.
5. After the pasta overflows: 'What went wrong? Why did this happen?'
6. Discuss the lesson: 'Why is it important to listen to ALL the instructions, not just part of them?'

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this book cover! It's called Strega Nona, which is a fun Italian name. We're going to read a story today that comes all the way from a faraway place called Italy.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Place the globe nearby to show Italy.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few special things! We need the Strega Nona book, of course, and a map or globe so we can find Italy. We also need our drawing supplies to make something super fun later!

slides.text: 'This story is from Italy — let us find Italy on the map! It looks like a boot. Italian food is famous around the world. This story is about a magic pasta pot.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this map! See this part that looks like a boot? That's Italy, where our story comes from! They eat yummy pasta there, and this story is all about a magic pasta pot.

slides.text: Read aloud. When Big Anthony decides to use the pot: 'He only heard PART of the instructions. Is that a good idea?' Let the child predict.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story! Listen carefully to what happens when a character named Big Anthony tries to use the magic pot. He only heard some of the words. Do you think that's a good idea? What do you think will happen?

slides.text: As the town fills with pasta: 'Oh no! What would YOU do? How can they stop it?' Build suspense.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh my goodness, look at all that pasta! It's everywhere! What would you do if you were here? How do you think they can stop all that pasta from coming out?

slides.prompt: Draw the funniest part of the story — the town covered in pasta! Or draw what YOU would do if you had a magic pasta pot. What food would yours make?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be artists! Let's draw the funniest part of the story, maybe the town full of pasta! Or, you can draw what food your own magic pasta pot would make. I can't wait to see your amazing pictures!

slides.text: 'Big Anthony learned an important lesson: always listen to ALL the instructions! That is why we follow each step in our work carefully.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Big Anthony's plan failed and connect it to the importance of following complete instructions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Big Anthony learned that it's super important to listen to *all* the instructions, not just some of them. That's why we always follow every step when we do our activities, just like Big Anthony should have! You did such a great job listening today!

parent_notes: Strega Nona is a perfect end-of-week read-aloud that connects to multiple curriculum areas: geography (Italy/Europe), practical life (following instructions in cooking), and grace and courtesy (listening carefully). The story's humor — a whole town drowning in pasta — delights children while teaching a serious lesson about responsibility and consequences. The Italian cultural element ties to the puzzle map work this week. If you have time, making simple pasta together after the story brings it to life. Tomie dePaola's illustrations are warm and distinctive. This is the first book in a beloved series — the child may want to read more Strega Nona stories.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together
